title: Numbers Chapter 22 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Numbers chapter 22 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Numbers Chapter 22 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Numbers Chapter 22.

questions.question: Where did the children of Israel pitch their camp as they set forward?
options: In the plains of Moab on this side Jordan by Jericho
In the wilderness of Sinai
At Mount Horeb
By the Red Sea
questions.correctAnswer: In the plains of Moab on this side Jordan by Jericho
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:1 states that the children of Israel set forward and pitched in the plains of Moab on this side Jordan by Jericho.

questions.question: Who was the king of the Moabites during this time?
options: Balak, the son of Zippor
Balaam, the son of Beor
Zippor, the son of Balak
Joshua, son of Nun
questions.correctAnswer: Balak, the son of Zippor
questions.explanation: According to Numbers 22:4, Balak the son of Zippor was king of the Moabites at that time.

questions.question: What did Balak want Balaam to do to the Israelites?
options: Curse the people of Israel
Bless the people of Israel
Lead the Israelites into battle
Give a prophecy of peace
questions.correctAnswer: Curse the people of Israel
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:6 shows Balak asking Balaam to curse the people because they were too mighty for him.

questions.question: What did God tell Balaam about going with the Moabite princes the first time they came to him?
options: Thou shalt not go with them; thou shalt not curse the people
Go and curse the people as they ask
Bless the people instead of cursing
Wait for further instructions
questions.correctAnswer: Thou shalt not go with them; thou shalt not curse the people
questions.explanation: God told Balaam in Numbers 22:12 that he should not go with them and not curse the people as they were blessed.

questions.question: How did Balaam respond when Balak sent more honorable princes to call him?
options: He said he could only do what the LORD tells him
He immediately agreed to go
He cursed the people there and then
He ignored their message
questions.correctAnswer: He said he could only do what the LORD tells him
questions.explanation: In Numbers 22:18, Balaam said he could not go beyond the word of the LORD to do less or more.

questions.question: What did God instruct Balaam to do when the men came to call him again at night?
options: Rise up and go with them, but only say what I tell you
Refuse to go no matter what
Curse the people immediately
Hide from the men
questions.correctAnswer: Rise up and go with them, but only say what I tell you
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:20 records God telling Balaam to go if the men come, but to speak only the word God gives him.

questions.question: What creature did Balaam ride on as he went with the princes of Moab?
options: An ass
A horse
A camel
A chariot
questions.correctAnswer: An ass
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:21 tells us that Balaam saddled his ass and went with the princes of Moab.

questions.question: Why did the angel of the LORD stand in Balaam's way?
options: Because Balaam's way was perverse before God
To bless Balaam on his journey
To guide Balaam safely
To give Balaam a new message
questions.correctAnswer: Because Balaam's way was perverse before God
questions.explanation: In Numbers 22:32, the angel of the LORD said he went out to withstand Balaam because his way was perverse before God.

questions.question: How did Balaam react when his ass spoke to him?
options: He was angry and wished he had a sword to kill the ass
He was amazed and praised the LORD
He immediately repented
He ran away from the ass
questions.correctAnswer: He was angry and wished he had a sword to kill the ass
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:29 shows Balaam saying he wished there was a sword in his hand to kill the ass for mocking him.

questions.question: What did the LORD do so Balaam could see the angel of the LORD?
options: Opened the eyes of Balaam
Spoke to Balaam directly
Sent a loud voice
Made Balaam fall asleep
questions.correctAnswer: Opened the eyes of Balaam
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:31 says the LORD opened Balaam's eyes so he saw the angel of the LORD standing in the way.

questions.question: True or False: Balak was able to convince Balaam to curse the Israelites immediately upon his arrival.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The text shows Balaam only spoke the word God gave him and did not curse the Israelites immediately (Numbers 22:38).

questions.question: True or False: The ass turned aside three times to avoid the angel of the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:23-27 describe the ass turning aside three times to avoid the angel of the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Balaam said he had power to say anything he wished when he came to Balak.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: In Numbers 22:38 Balaam said he had no power to say anything but only what God put in his mouth.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Numbers 22:6: 'Come now therefore, I pray thee, curse me this people; for they are too _____ for me.'
options: mighty
weak
numerous
far
questions.correctAnswer: mighty
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:6 uses the word 'mighty' to describe the people being too strong for Balak.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Numbers 22:28: 'And the LORD opened the mouth of the ass, and she said unto Balaam, What have I done unto thee, that thou hast smitten me these _____ times?'
options: three
two
four
five
questions.correctAnswer: three
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:28 records the ass saying Balaam had smitten her three times.

medium.title: Numbers Chapter 22 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Numbers Chapter 22 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is facing opposition and fears defeat. Based on Numbers 22, what biblical truth about God's blessing would you share?
options: God blesses His people and those He blesses cannot be cursed.
Might and numbers guarantee victory over enemies.
Human plans can override God's will.
Curses are more powerful than blessings.
questions.correctAnswer: God blesses His people and those He blesses cannot be cursed.
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:6, 12, and 18 show that Balaam knew those blessed by God are protected from curses. God's blessing is sovereign and cannot be overturned by human efforts.

questions.question: How does Numbers 22 teach us about obedience to God when Balaam was instructed not to go with the Moabite princes?
options: Balaam initially obeyed God's command and refused to go.
Balaam ignored God's command and went immediately.
Balaam cursed the Israelites as requested.
Balaam did not consult God before deciding.
questions.correctAnswer: Balaam initially obeyed God's command and refused to go.
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:12-13 shows Balaam obeyed God by refusing to go when first asked. This teaches the importance of waiting on God's direction before acting.

questions.question: What does Balaam’s response to Balak’s offer of great honor teach us about integrity in daily life?
options: Balaam said he could not go beyond God's word, showing integrity.
Balaam accepted the honor and cursed Israel for money.
Balaam ignored God's commands for personal gain.
Balaam demanded more rewards before deciding.
questions.correctAnswer: Balaam said he could not go beyond God's word, showing integrity.
questions.explanation: In Numbers 22:18, Balaam declares he cannot do less or more than what God commands, illustrating honesty and integrity even under temptation.

questions.question: A believer is struggling to discern God’s will. How does Balaam’s experience in Numbers 22 encourage us about seeking God’s guidance?
options: Balaam sought God repeatedly and waited for His word before acting.
Balaam acted without consulting God.
Balaam relied on his own understanding alone.
Balaam ignored God's instructions initially.
questions.correctAnswer: Balaam sought God repeatedly and waited for His word before acting.
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:8-9, 19-20 show Balaam’s pattern of prayerful waiting and listening to God, emphasizing the importance of seeking God’s guidance in decisions.

questions.question: What lesson about humility and contentment can be drawn from Balaam’s reaction after seeing the angel of the LORD?
options: Balaam admitted his sin and was willing to turn back if displeasing God.
Balaam refused to acknowledge his mistake.
Balaam blamed his donkey for the problem.
Balaam continued on his own path stubbornly.
questions.correctAnswer: Balaam admitted his sin and was willing to turn back if displeasing God.
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:34 records Balaam’s confession and willingness to obey God’s will, demonstrating humility and readiness to submit to God’s discipline.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise God's Word for personal gain. Based on Numbers 22, what principle would you emphasize?
options: God’s Word must not be compromised regardless of rewards.
Personal gain justifies bending God’s Word.
Honoring men is more important than obeying God.
One should seek blessings through any means.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s Word must not be compromised regardless of rewards.
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:18 and 35 highlight Balaam’s commitment to speak only what God commands, teaching the importance of faithfulness and integrity.

questions.question: What does the story of Balaam’s talking donkey teach us about patience and self-control when dealing with frustration?
options: Balaam’s anger led him to strike his donkey, showing a lack of patience.
Balaam remained calm throughout the journey.
Balaam immediately recognized his error without frustration.
The donkey ignored Balaam’s treatment.
questions.correctAnswer: Balaam’s anger led him to strike his donkey, showing a lack of patience.
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:23-29 shows Balaam’s frustration and harsh response before understanding God’s purpose, teaching the need for patience and self-control in trials.

questions.question: True or False: According to Numbers 22, Balaam only obeyed God’s word after God softened his heart and opened his eyes to the angel of the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:31-35 shows that after God opened Balaam’s eyes to see the angel, Balaam acknowledged his sin and committed to obeying God's instruction.

questions.question: How does Numbers 22 illustrate the importance of trusting God’s protection in the face of overwhelming fear?
options: Moab was afraid of Israel’s great numbers but God’s blessing protected Israel.
Moab’s fear led them to defeat Israel without a fight.
Israel relied on their own strength to conquer Moab.
Balak successfully cursed Israel with human power.
questions.correctAnswer: Moab was afraid of Israel’s great numbers but God’s blessing protected Israel.
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:3-4 and 6-12 demonstrate Moab’s fear of Israel’s multitude but God’s blessing ensured Israel’s safety against curses and attacks.

questions.question: What does the dialogue between Balaam and the angel of the LORD teach about God’s discipline and guidance?
options: God disciplines to correct and guide us away from perverse paths.
God allows unchecked disobedience without intervention.
God’s angels do not influence human decisions.
Discipline is only for punishment, not for guidance.
questions.correctAnswer: God disciplines to correct and guide us away from perverse paths.
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:32-33 shows the angel confronting Balaam to prevent his perverse way, teaching that God’s discipline aims to steer us back to obedience.

questions.question: In Numbers 22, Balak repeatedly sends princes to persuade Balaam. What does this teach about perseverance in prayer and waiting on God's timing?
options: Balaam waited for God’s clear word before acting despite repeated requests.
Balaam gave in immediately to the first request.
Balaam ignored all requests without prayer.
Balaam acted on his own timing, not God’s.
questions.correctAnswer: Balaam waited for God’s clear word before acting despite repeated requests.
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:7-20 illustrates Balaam’s repeated consultations with God before going, teaching the value of perseverance and reliance on God’s timing.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Balaam told Balak, 'I cannot go beyond the word of the LORD my God, to do _____ or ____.'
options: less, more
right, wrong
good, evil
fast, slow
questions.correctAnswer: less, more
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:18 shows Balaam’s commitment to obey exactly what God commands, neither doing less nor more than His Word.

questions.question: How does Numbers 22 teach about the importance of spiritual discernment in leadership?
options: Balak sought Balaam’s curse, but only God knew the true outcome and blessing.
Leaders should rely solely on human wisdom.
Prophets should ignore divine guidance for political gain.
Leadership is based on popularity, not spiritual insight.
questions.correctAnswer: Balak sought Balaam’s curse, but only God knew the true outcome and blessing.
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:5-6 and 12 show that despite human plans, God’s will prevails, teaching leaders to seek and submit to divine discernment.

questions.question: True or False: Balaam’s donkey was able to see the angel of the LORD before Balaam himself did.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:23-28 describes how the donkey saw the angel standing in the way and turned aside, while Balaam was initially unaware.

questions.question: When Balaam saw the angel of the LORD with a drawn sword, what was his response and what does this teach about reverence before God?
options: He bowed down and fell flat on his face, showing reverence and submission.
He drew his own sword to fight.
He ignored the angel and continued on.
He argued with the angel about his plans.
questions.correctAnswer: He bowed down and fell flat on his face, showing reverence and submission.
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:31 records Balaam’s humble posture before the angel, teaching the importance of reverence and submission to God’s authority.

questions.question: What does Balak’s repeated attempts to hire Balaam teach us about the need for spiritual discernment in responding to worldly offers?
options: Believers must discern God’s will and not be swayed by worldly rewards.
It is wise to accept all offers to gain honor.
God prefers that we use human wisdom over His instructions.
Spiritual discernment is unnecessary when rewards are great.
questions.correctAnswer: Believers must discern God’s will and not be swayed by worldly rewards.
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:15-17 shows Balak’s enticing offers, but Balaam’s response in 22:18 and 35 highlights the need for spiritual discernment and obedience over worldly gain.

hard.title: Numbers Chapter 22 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Numbers Chapter 22.

questions.question: What was the initial reason for Balak sending messengers to Balaam?
options: To curse the Israelites who were too mighty
To bless the Israelites for peace
To recruit Balaam as a military leader
To seek an alliance against Midian
questions.correctAnswer: To curse the Israelites who were too mighty
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:5-6 shows Balak sending messengers to Balaam to curse Israel because they were mighty and a threat.

questions.question: How did Balaam initially respond to Balak's request to curse Israel?
options: He refused because God did not permit him
He immediately agreed to curse Israel
He asked for a large sum of silver
He sought permission from the elders of Midian
questions.correctAnswer: He refused because God did not permit him
questions.explanation: According to Numbers 22:12-13, Balaam said he could not go because God had refused to let him curse Israel.

questions.question: What literary device is illustrated by the narrative of Balaam's donkey speaking?
options: Anthropomorphism
Chiasm
Typology
Parable
questions.correctAnswer: Anthropomorphism
questions.explanation: In Numbers 22:28, the donkey is given human speech, a clear example of anthropomorphism.

questions.question: What was God's attitude when Balaam went with the princes of Moab?
options: God's anger was kindled
God blessed Balaam
God was indifferent
God sent an angel to protect Balaam
questions.correctAnswer: God's anger was kindled
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:22 states that God's anger was kindled because Balaam went with the princes.

questions.question: Which Old Testament theme is foreshadowed by the angel of the LORD opposing Balaam's way?
options: Divine judgment on disobedience
The establishment of the Davidic kingdom
Covenantal blessings to Israel
The exile to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: Divine judgment on disobedience
questions.explanation: The angel opposing Balaam in Numbers 22:32 represents divine judgment against disobedient paths.

questions.question: What was the significance of Balaam stating he could not go beyond the word of the LORD?
options: It emphasizes divine sovereignty over human will
It shows Balaam's financial greed
It highlights Balak's authority
It reveals the power of Midianite elders
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes divine sovereignty over human will
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:18 shows Balaam refusing to act contrary to God's command, underscoring God's control.

questions.question: What cultural or historical context is evident in Balak's offer to promote Balaam to 'very great honour'?
options: Ancient Near Eastern practice of patronage for diviners
Greek philosophical traditions
Roman legal contracts
Egyptian monarchical decrees
questions.correctAnswer: Ancient Near Eastern practice of patronage for diviners
questions.explanation: Balak's promise in Numbers 22:17 reflects the common ancient Near Eastern custom of rewarding prophets or diviners for their services.

questions.question: In what way does the story of Balaam connect intertextually with the New Testament?
options: 2 Peter 2:15 references Balaam's greed and error
The parable of the Good Samaritan
The Sermon on the Mount
The Book of Revelation’s visions
questions.correctAnswer: 2 Peter 2:15 references Balaam's greed and error
questions.explanation: The New Testament in 2 Peter 2:15 mentions Balaam's error and greed, linking back to this chapter's narrative.

questions.question: How does the motif of the donkey seeing the angel relate to biblical symbolism?
options: It symbolizes spiritual insight where humans are blind
It represents animal worship in Moab
It denotes demonic possession
It indicates Balaam's divine favor
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes spiritual insight where humans are blind
questions.explanation: The donkey's ability to see the angel (Numbers 22:23-28) compared to Balaam's blindness is symbolic of spiritual perception.

questions.question: Which Hebrew term describing God's interaction with Balaam underscores the divine initiative in prophetic communication?
options: Vayehi (and it came to pass)
Shalom (peace)
Chesed (lovingkindness)
Ruach (spirit)
questions.correctAnswer: Vayehi (and it came to pass)
questions.explanation: The phrase 'And God came unto Balaam' (Numbers 22:9, 22:20) uses the Hebrew vayehi, emphasizing God's active engagement.

questions.question: What is the significance of the location 'plains of Moab on this side Jordan by Jericho' in Israel’s journey?
options: It marks the final approach to the Promised Land
It is the site of Israel's first major battle
It is where the tabernacle was first erected
It is the location of Moses' birth
questions.correctAnswer: It marks the final approach to the Promised Land
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:1 identifies the plains of Moab near Jericho as the staging ground before Israel enters Canaan.

questions.question: True or False: Balak was confident he could overcome Israel without supernatural help.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Balak expressed his fear and need for Balaam's curse because Israel was too mighty (Numbers 22:6).

questions.question: What does Balak's repeated sending of more honorable princes to Balaam suggest about his intentions?
options: He was desperate to secure Balaam's cooperation
He sought to negotiate a peace treaty
He intended to spy on Balaam
He was trying to convert Balaam to worship Baal
questions.correctAnswer: He was desperate to secure Balaam's cooperation
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:15-16 shows Balak escalating his diplomatic effort by sending more honorable princes.

questions.question: Which theme in Numbers 22 is developed across Scripture concerning blessing and cursing?
options: The irrevocability of God's blessing and curse
The power of human will over divine decree
The neutrality of divine judgment
The equality of blessings and curses
questions.correctAnswer: The irrevocability of God's blessing and curse
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:6 reflects the belief that whoever God blesses is blessed and whoever He curses is cursed, a theme developed throughout Scripture.

questions.question: How does Balaam’s behavior in this chapter reflect the tension between prophetic obedience and personal gain?
options: He insists he cannot act beyond God's word despite Balak's rewards
He immediately curses Israel for silver and gold
He flees from Balak to avoid the mission
He uses the opportunity to preach repentance
questions.correctAnswer: He insists he cannot act beyond God's word despite Balak's rewards
questions.explanation: In Numbers 22:18, Balaam declares he will not go beyond God's word even if offered great wealth.

questions.question: What is the significance of Balak bringing Balaam to the high places of Baal?
options: To get a better vantage point to see Israel
To perform Baal worship rituals
To hide Balaam from the Israelites
To offer sacrifices to God
questions.correctAnswer: To get a better vantage point to see Israel
questions.explanation: Numbers 22:41 states Balak took Balaam to the high places of Baal to see the utmost part of the people.

theological.title: Numbers Chapter 22 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Numbers Chapter 22 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was Balak's primary reason for summoning Balaam to curse the Israelites?
options: Because the Israelites were too mighty and might drive Moab out of the land
To form a political alliance with Israel
To bless the Israelites for their faithfulness
To request military aid against the Amorites
questions.correctAnswer: Because the Israelites were too mighty and might drive Moab out of the land
questions.explanation: Balak feared Israel because they were numerous and might overpower Moab, so he sought Balaam to curse them (Numbers 22:5-6). This reflects God's providence in protecting His people (Psalm 33:10-12; Deuteronomy 28:7; Romans 8:31; Revelation 7:3).

questions.question: What was God's initial response to Balaam regarding the request to curse Israel?
options: Do not go with them and do not curse the people because they are blessed
Go immediately and curse the people
Wait until further instructions
Bless the people and curse Moab instead
questions.correctAnswer: Do not go with them and do not curse the people because they are blessed
questions.explanation: God explicitly forbids Balaam from cursing Israel because they are blessed by God (Numbers 22:12). This underscores God's sovereign blessing on His covenant people, consistent with Genesis 12:3; Psalm 105:15; Romans 11:29; Galatians 3:8.

questions.question: How did Balaam describe his ability to act in relation to God's word?
options: He cannot do less or more than what God commands
He can act according to his own will
He can bless or curse freely
He will decide based on the rewards offered
questions.correctAnswer: He cannot do less or more than what God commands
questions.explanation: Balaam acknowledged that his actions are bound strictly by God's command, highlighting divine sovereignty and prophetic submission (Numbers 22:18). This principle aligns with Isaiah 55:11; Jeremiah 1:9-10; Ezekiel 2:7; John 12:49.

questions.question: What was the reason for God's anger towards Balaam when he went with the princes of Moab?
options: Because Balaam went despite God's instructions
Because Balaam cursed Israel
Because Balaam refused to go
Because Balaam blessed Moab
questions.correctAnswer: Because Balaam went despite God's instructions
questions.explanation: God's anger was kindled because Balaam went with the men, even though God had previously forbidden him to curse Israel (Numbers 22:22). This demonstrates God's holiness and justice in restraining disobedient actions (Exodus 20:5; Psalm 7:11; Nahum 1:2; Hebrews 12:29).

questions.question: What supernatural event involving Balaam’s donkey occurred on the journey?
options: The donkey spoke to Balaam after seeing the angel of the LORD
The donkey miraculously grew wings
The donkey ran away and disappeared
The donkey was turned into a man
questions.correctAnswer: The donkey spoke to Balaam after seeing the angel of the LORD
questions.explanation: God opened the mouth of the donkey, which spoke to Balaam about the reason for its behavior, revealing God's intervention and Balaam's spiritual blindness (Numbers 22:28). This miracle emphasizes God’s control over creation (Exodus 4:10-12; 1 Kings 22:28-29; Luke 1:20; Acts 9:4).

questions.question: What was Balaam’s response after seeing the angel of the LORD?
options: He bowed down and admitted his sin
He ignored the angel and continued
He cursed the donkey
He fled from the angel
questions.correctAnswer: He bowed down and admitted his sin
questions.explanation: Upon seeing the angel, Balaam bowed and confessed his ignorance and sin, showing repentance and submission to God's authority (Numbers 22:31-34). This reflects biblical themes of humility before God (Psalm 95:6; Isaiah 57:15; James 4:10; 1 John 1:9).

questions.question: What condition did God place on Balaam when He told him to go with the men?
options: Only to speak the word God gives him
To curse Israel as requested
To accept Balak's rewards before speaking
To bless Moab instead of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Only to speak the word God gives him
questions.explanation: God permitted Balaam to go but commanded him to speak only the words God would give him, demonstrating divine control over prophetic speech (Numbers 22:35). This principle aligns with Deuteronomy 18:18-19; Jeremiah 23:28-29; Amos 3:7; Acts 3:22.

questions.question: Where did Balak meet Balaam upon his arrival in Moab?
options: A city of Moab on the border of Arnon
Jericho
Pethor by the river
The plains of Moab
questions.correctAnswer: A city of Moab on the border of Arnon
questions.explanation: Balak met Balaam at a city in Moab near the border of Arnon, indicating the strategic location for viewing Israel (Numbers 22:36). This situates the narrative geographically and historically (Joshua 13:9; Deuteronomy 2:24; Psalm 78:55; Numbers 21:13).

questions.question: How did Balaam describe his power to speak when questioned by Balak?
options: He had no power except to speak the word God put in his mouth
He could speak whatever Balak desired
He claimed to have great personal authority
He would curse or bless as he pleased
questions.correctAnswer: He had no power except to speak the word God put in his mouth
questions.explanation: Balaam acknowledged that his authority was limited to God's word, emphasizing prophetic dependence on divine revelation (Numbers 22:38). This corresponds with prophetic humility seen in Jeremiah 1:9; Ezekiel 3:27; Psalm 119:105; John 7:16.

questions.question: What offering did Balak present to Balaam after he arrived?
options: Oxen and sheep
Gold and silver
Grain and wine
Wood and incense
questions.correctAnswer: Oxen and sheep
questions.explanation: Balak offered oxen and sheep to Balaam, a common practice for seeking divine favor and fellowship, reflecting covenantal ritual acts (Numbers 22:40). This is consistent with Leviticus 1:3; Genesis 15:9; Hebrews 9:22; Exodus 24:5.

questions.question: From where did Balak intend for Balaam to view the Israelite camp?
options: The high places of Baal
The plains of Moab
The city of Jericho
The river Jordan
questions.correctAnswer: The high places of Baal
questions.explanation: Balak took Balaam to the high places of Baal to see the utmost part of the people, intending Balaam to curse them from a vantage point (Numbers 22:41). This locates the scene in a cultic setting, highlighting idolatry contrasts (1 Kings 18:20; 2 Kings 23:5; Deuteronomy 12:2; Psalm 115:4-8).

questions.question: How did the elders of Moab and Midian prepare before speaking with Balaam?
options: They carried rewards of divination in their hand
They fasted and prayed
They brought sacrifices of incense
They wore ceremonial robes
questions.correctAnswer: They carried rewards of divination in their hand
questions.explanation: The elders came with rewards of divination, indicating an intent to bribe or influence Balaam, revealing human sinfulness and corruption (Numbers 22:7). This theme recurs in biblical warnings (Micah 3:11; Deuteronomy 18:10-12; Ezekiel 13:9; 2 Peter 2:15).

questions.question: What analogy did Moab use to describe the threat of Israel?
options: A company that will lick up all around them as an ox licks up the grass
A lion that devours its prey
A flood that covers the land
A fire that consumes the forest
questions.correctAnswer: A company that will lick up all around them as an ox licks up the grass
questions.explanation: Moab compared Israel to an ox licking up grass, illustrating the rapid and complete consumption of territory, highlighting the fear of Israel's expansion (Numbers 22:4). This metaphor relates to God’s judgment and providence (Isaiah 10:27; Ezekiel 34:27; Psalm 72:3; Revelation 19:15).

questions.question: What was the nature of Balaam’s journey with the princes of Moab according to God's command?
options: He was allowed to go but only to speak the word God would give
He was to lead them against Israel
He was to curse Israel as instructed
He was to negotiate peace with Israel
questions.correctAnswer: He was allowed to go but only to speak the word God would give
questions.explanation: God’s command was clear that Balaam could go but must only speak the word God provided, which illustrates divine sovereignty over prophecy and human agency (Numbers 22:20, 35). This is consistent with prophetic ministry in Scripture (Deuteronomy 18:18; Jeremiah 27:16; Amos 3:7; Acts 3:22).

questions.question: What does Balaam’s interaction with the donkey reveal about his spiritual perception?
options: He was spiritually blind until God opened his eyes
He possessed great spiritual insight from the start
He always understood God's will clearly
He had no need for divine revelation
questions.correctAnswer: He was spiritually blind until God opened his eyes
questions.explanation: Balaam did not see the angel until God opened his eyes, reflecting human spiritual blindness and the necessity of divine revelation (Numbers 22:31). This aligns with John 9:39-41; 2 Corinthians 4:4; Isaiah 6:9-10; Ephesians 1:18.
